Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client’s case grows more complex and requires detailed guidance
Story: I stared at my calendar, the blocks of time bleeding into each other. As a software developer, I was expected to join the upcoming brainstorming session with the product team. It was marked as “optional,” but I knew from experience that my absence would be noticed. My input on new features was valued, and skipping the session could mean missing out on shaping the product’s direction. At the same time, my role as an advocate weighed heavily on me. One of my clients had just sent a frantic email—her case was growing more complex by the hour, and she needed detailed, accurate legal advice. She was counting on me to guide her through the maze of regulations and options. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides: the team’s unspoken expectation that I’d be present and engaged, and my client’s urgent need for clarity. My mind raced, torn between the collaborative energy of the brainstorming session and the responsibility I felt toward my client. I sat at my desk, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
